pull.title: fuzz: add low-level target for txorphanage
pull.body:
This adds a low-level fuzz target for orphan transaction handling by creating random transactions and calling all functions in `TxOrphanage`.
It cannot simulate real-world `orphan/unorphan` scenarios effectively since it does not maintain any state about the node and the chain. A high-level fuzz target which construct well-designed transaction graphs will be added later.

rename.from: fuzz: add low level target for txorphanage
rename.to: fuzz: add low-level target for txorphanage

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#25527](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25527) ([kernel 3c/n] Decouple validation cache initialization from `ArgsManager` by dongcarl)
* [#25324](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25324) (refactor: add most of src/util to iwyu by fanquake)
* [#25227](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25227) (Handle invalid hex encoding in ParseHex by MarcoFalke)
* [#25112](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25112) (util: Move error message formatting of NonFatalCheckError to cpp by MarcoFalke)
* [#24974](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/24974) (refactor: Make FEELER_SLEEP_WINDOW type safe (std::chrono) by MarcoFalke)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.
If you want you can submit fuzz inputs to the qa-assets repo

Approach ACK.

While the existing process_messages target can achieve line coverage in this module, it fails to generate any meaningful path/branch coverage. So it makes sense to add a "unit" fuzz test.

events.message: fuzz: add low-level target for txorphanage

comments.body: nit: year

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,77 @@
+// Copyright (c) 2020-2021 The Bitcoin Core developers
+// Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+// file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+
+#include <random.h>
comments.body:
nondeterminism does not work nicely with whitebox and greybox fuzzing. It makes it impossible for fuzz engines to track coverage precisely. Ideally the full program execution is fully predetermined by the fuzz input exclusively.

Please remove this and use `fuzzed_data_provider` instead.

```suggestion
```

nit: I think they are default initialized, so can remove them?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,77 @@
+// Copyright (c) 2020-2021 The Bitcoin Core developers
+// Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+// file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+
+#include <random.h>
+#include <primitives/transaction.h>
+#include <test/util/script.h>
+#include <test/fuzz/FuzzedDataProvider.h>
+#include <test/fuzz/fuzz.h>
+#include <test/fuzz/util.h>
+#include <txorphanage.h>
+
+
+FUZZ_TARGET(orphanage)
+{
+    FuzzedDataProvider fuzzed_data_provider(buffer.data(), buffer.size());
+
+    TxOrphanage orphanage;
+    std::set<uint256> orphan_work_set;
+
+    LIMITED_WHILE(fuzzed_data_provider.ConsumeBool(), COINBASE_MATURITY)
comments.body: any reason to use `COINBASE_MATURITY` here? Shouldn't this be a constant derived from `TxOrphanage` internals? For example a bit larger than the maximum set size?

It might be better to pick either:

* an existing prevout of a previously created transaction
* a random hash

Otherwise you are only ever testing one generation of txs.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,77 @@
+// Copyright (c) 2020-2021 The Bitcoin Core developers
+// Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying

+#include <test/fuzz/fuzz.h>

+#include <txorphanage.h>
+
+
+FUZZ_TARGET(orphanage)
+{
+    FuzzedDataProvider fuzzed_data_provider(buffer.data(), buffer.size());
+
+    TxOrphanage orphanage;
+    std::set<uint256> orphan_work_set;
+
+    LIMITED_WHILE(fuzzed_data_provider.ConsumeBool(), COINBASE_MATURITY)
comments.body: Already changed to `DEFAULT_MAX_ORPHAN_TRANSACTIONS`

Thanks for your advice. You mean we'd better consider parent relationships when constructing transactions even they are not completely valid? I have changed the code to keep transactions (actually `CTransactionRef`) in a set, from which `prevout` will be picked for later inputs. 
However, now it has two differences compared to `tx_pool_standard` target.

- `tx_pool_standard` keep a set of **outpoints**, while I keep **transactions**
- `tx_pool_standard` fill the outpoints initially by `MineBlock` results, while I construct initial transactions using random hashes.

I am not sure which strategy is better.
I think a set of outpoints is better. In your current approach you create `first_tx` -> (second tx) -> (third tx) ... This is a plain chain. Ideally there are some more complicated graphs.

comments.body: I think a basic testing setup (args and logging) is sufficient. No need for a chain here in this simple test.

comments.body: Yeah, I think it might be preferable to just construct it manually. However, if you switch to an outpoints approach, you'll probably need to create a few outpoints manually instead.

I think you can just create a few outpoints by calling the `COutPoint` constructor and passing a txid of 0 or 1 or so. This should be so cheap that it doesn't have to be done in the global setup, but can be done local in the fuzz target itself.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,110 @@

+// Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+// file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+
+#include <net_processing.h>

+} // namespace

+{
+    static const auto testing_setup = MakeNoLogFileContext<const TestingSetup>();
+    g_setup = testing_setup.get();
+    SyncWithValidationInterfaceQueue();
comments.body:
Please keep the `MakeNoLogFileContext` in init. It is not strictly needed, but I think it is nice to have to have a logger and argsmanager initialized for testing.

The reason is that they are currently globals, so they may be used at any time during runtime or in future code changes without the fuzz test noticing. And if they are used, we want them to be initialized for testing and not accidentally corrupt the main datadir (or cause OOMs) or other bugs.

```suggestion
            // pick unique outpoints from outpoints as input
```

nit

```suggestion
                tx_mut.vout.emplace_back(CAmount{}, CScript{});
```

nit: No need for any script
why?

```suggestion
        LIMITED_WHILE(fuzzed_data_provider.ConsumeBool(), 10 * DEFAULT_MAX_ORPHAN_TRANSACTIONS)
```

nit: I think this can be larger, unless it takes a long time?
could assert that the return value is equal to the one of `HaveTx` here?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,97 @@
+// Copyright (c) 2022 The Bitcoin Core developers
+// Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+// file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+
+#include <net_processing.h>
comments.body: `DEFAULT_MAX_ORPHAN_TRANSACTIONS` is defined in `net_processing.h`

The loop are used to fill the tx's `vout`, you mean it is not necessary since we don't have any code that verifies content of `vout`? Should we replace it with `tx.vout.resize(num_out)` or just keep `vout` empty?
Oh, I meant why it is needed or what the goal is to *restore previously removed outpoints*

There are two `LIMITED_WHILE` loops in the file, the outer loop determines how many transactions can be constructed, and the inner loop (the one you suggested) determines how many times can `TxOrphange` methods be triggered. I am not sure about the exact value to be set. I think it can be bigger, though the probability of actually reaching the limit may be very low.

This is because the tx_pool_standard target does the accounting later on, depending on whether the tx was accepted or not https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/cc22bd7f708fc3f5e793bf0138cd340f71c0feb9/src/test/fuzz/tx_pool.cpp#L296

However, your fuzz target does not have a concept of "rejected" transactions right now. Does it?

If you want to "restore" the outpoints, it might be better to not delete them in the first place.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,97 @@
+// Copyright (c) 2022 The Bitcoin Core developers
+// Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+// file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+
+#include <net_processing.h>
+#include <primitives/transaction.h>
+#include <test/fuzz/FuzzedDataProvider.h>
+#include <test/fuzz/fuzz.h>
+#include <test/fuzz/util.h>
+#include <test/util/mining.h>
+#include <test/util/script.h>
+#include <test/util/setup_common.h>
+#include <txorphanage.h>
+#include <validation.h>
+
+
+FUZZ_TARGET(orphanage)
+{
+    FuzzedDataProvider fuzzed_data_provider(buffer.data(), buffer.size());
+
+    TxOrphanage orphanage;
+    std::set<uint256> orphan_work_set;
+    std::set<COutPoint> outpoints;
comments.body: I think this might be better as std::vector, to get a more stable, predictable sorting

Thanks for your explanation. There is no "rejected" transaction right now. The outpoint is "deleted" from the set whenever it is picked as an input of the tx to ensure it will not be selected again. Once the construction of the tx is finished, all "deleted" transactions, which are exactly the inputs of the constructed tx, are "recovered". All the process happens within the construction of tx.

So it seems has nothing to do with the later accounting which is considered in `tx_pool_standard`.

I think you'll need to use SetMockTime throughout the test to expire txs
Also there is a non-deterministic FastRandomContext in this function, but I guess it won't be possible to fix that without touching non-fuzz code.

Maybe a bool (determined at the beginning of the fuzz input) can indicate whether this run may have duplicate inputs in txs or not?

